p: Polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) is a polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA), which is produced by certain bacteria as intracellular storage compound. PHAs can be used as bioplastics, replacing fossil-based plastics produced from mineral oil components. Production of PHAs by microorganisms has been investigated during the last years; however, production costs were usually too high to achieve a substantial replacement of plastic from fossil resources. Identification of cheap carbon sources for the microbial production of PHA may be one approach to decrease production costs. AFEX-pretreated wheat straw was used for PHB production with Burkholderia sacchari. An intracellular PHB concentration of 72% was achieved within 61 h of cultivation, corresponding to 105 g/l PHB (Cesário et al. 2014). Rice straw hydrolysate obtained from alkaline pretreatment was used as substrate for Ralstonia eutropha to produce PHB. An intracellular PHB concentration of 75% was achieved within 48 h of cultivation, corresponding to a total PHB concentration of 11.4 g/l (Saratale and Oh 2015).
